raw_text:
Sella wants Michalak recall
 
 Former France centre Philippe Sella believes coach Bernard Laporte must recall Frederic Michalak to give his side any chance of beating Ireland.
 
 Sella admitted he had been impressed by current fly-half Yann Delaigue in the RBS Six Nations to date. But he told BBC Sport: "Michalak is the answer both now and for the future. Delaigue deserved his chance but the time has come to bring back Michalak. "He does have weaknesses but has the all-round game to upset Ireland." The 22-year-old Michalak has spent much of the tournament on the bench after Delaigue impressed for Castres early in the season. With Michalak overlooked, the French stuttered to narrow wins over Scotland and then England before ironically playing their best rugby in the defeat to Wales. "The Wales game was amazing to watch but never did I think the French could lose that game at half-time," said Sella.
 
 "Their only mistakes were that they didn't score enough points in the first half and were a little bit less focused in the second... but only a little bit." Sella, however, insisted the pressure had eased on the under-fire Laporte, despite the defeat at the Stade de France. "This season is very important for shaping a team for the 2007 World Cup," said Sella, "which Laporte is doing very well. The French get better every game. "It's difficult, though, when you change a team and you change your tactics as everything has to gel. "But he has the players and the talent to take them all the way to World Cup victory. "As a result, it is important that people give him time. It may not seem good now that we're not winning the Grand Slam but no one will care in two years time if we're world champions."
 
 The majority of media criticism centred on the way in which France produced a performance devoid of running rugby in their opening two games. But while Sella admitted he liked the more flowing style employed against Wales, he said "the win was most important". "Winning is all that matters," he added. "Ok, the flair may not have been so good, but the discipline, organisation and defence was there, which are all important ahead of 2007." France play what Sella believes is their hardest game of the Six Nations against Ireland in Dublin on Saturday 12 March. The French go into the game as clear underdogs. But Sella added: "People forget that France can still win the Six Nations and they'll be focused on that. "But Ireland will be going for even more in front of their home crowd. It's going to be tough."
llama3.2:1b: Former France centre Philippe Sella believes coach Bernard Laporte must recall current fly-half Frederic Michalak after Ireland, not Scotland or England, are the next opponents.
Sella had a good impression of Michalak and thinks he has the "all-round game" to beat Ireland.

Despite France's struggles this season, Sella believes the team is improving under Laporte and that Michalak will be able to lead them to victory in the final Six Nations match against Ireland on March 12th.
llama3.2:3b: Philippe Sella believes coach Bernard Laporte should recall Frederic Michalak to give France a chance against Ireland, citing Michalak's all-round game and the team's struggles without him.
Despite criticism over their performance, Sella thinks Laporte is doing well in preparing the team for the 2007 World Cup and praises the team's improvement each game.
gemma2:2b: Philippe Sella argues that Frederic Michalak should be recalled by coach Bernard Laporte to improve France's chances against Ireland.
He believes Michalak possesses a complete game and can upset the Irish despite his weaknesses, but acknowledges Yann Delaigue has earned his chance.
Sella praises Laporte's team development for the 2007 World Cup while emphasizing that patience is needed as France gets better with each game.
He also argues that winning is paramount in the Six Nations even if there isn’t flowing style.
The underdogs face a tough match against Ireland at Dublin on March 12th.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Former fly-half Philippe Sella claims it is important to bring back centre Frederic Michalak after the departure of Yann Delaigue.
Sella believes his side should not only win but also become "world champions" for 2007 World Cup by changing their tactics and team strategy.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Former France center Philippe Sella believes coach Bernard Laporte should recall Michalak, arguing he has the all-round game to upset Ireland, despite being overlooked due to Delaigue's performance.
qwen2.5:3b: Philippe Sella, former France centre, suggests Bernard Laporte should recall Frederic Michalak from the RBS Six Nations squad to give France a chance against Ireland.
Sella believes Michalak has both strengths and weaknesses but brings an all-round game that can unsettle Ireland.
Despite previous performance issues, Michalak's improved form at Castres is highlighted as evidence for his return.
Sella criticizes Laporte's team selection but maintains confidence in the coach's ability to shape a winning side for the 2007 World Cup.
He stresses the importance of focusing on discipline and defence rather than flair for France's upcoming game against Ireland, seen as a crucial contest with home advantage.

tinyllama:1.1b: SeLLA, a former France rugby coach, believes that coach Bernard Laporte should recall fly-half Yann Delaigue from the bench and bring back center Philippe Sella, who impressed with his all-round game, for Ireland's upcoming match against France in Dublin.
Sella has been critical of the team's style during their opening two matches but said it was crucial to win the Grand Slam to secure World Cup success.
The majority of media criticism centered on France's underperformance and flair, with some calling for a more disciplined approach against Ireland.
Nevertheless, Sella is confident in the team's ability to win their hardest game of the Six Nations.
In a post-match interview, Sella insisted that France will be focused on winning the tournament as they enter the match as underdogs.
However, he said it would take more than a win over Ireland for the team to secure World Cup success.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In a recent statement, France rugby coach Bernard Laporte is expected to recall former France center Philippe Sella to give his side any chance of beating Ireland during the Six Nations match in Dublin on Saturday.
According to sources familiar with the situation, Sella has been impressed by current fly-half Yann Delaigue and believes that Michalak deserves a chance to make an impact as the team's backline.
Sella was impressed with Delaigue's performance in recent weeks and hopes that his inclusion will improve France's overall game.
However, he acknowledged that the time has come for him to return to the bench after Delaigue impressively stepped in during a crucial moment against England.
"Michalak is the answer both now and for the future," Sella stated.
"Delaigue deserves his chance but the time has come for Michalak to show he deserves more game time."

Despite these recent performances, France's under-pressure coach Laporte may face criticism for not seizing this opportunity to bring back Michalak to improve their chances of victory against Ireland.
phi:2.7b: Philippe Sella believes French fly-half Frederic Michalak is essential for the team to have any chance at beating Ireland, despite Yann Delaigue's impressive performance so far in the tournament.
France has struggled with running rugby but still managed to put up a good fight against Wales and England.
Laporte is handling the pressure well, but Sella emphasizes that time is needed for him and his team to gel with their new tactics.
While France may not be winning the Grand Slam yet, they will likely forget about it in two years if they win the World Cup.
The majority of media criticism has been on the lack of running rugby, but Sella believes the team's discipline, organization, and defense are just as important for a successful campaign in 2007.

The French stumbled against Wales after a solid performance in their opening two games, with critics focusing on the lack of running rugby in those matches.

However, Sella stressed that winning was the most important factor, and while he liked the more flowing style employed against Wales, the majority of media criticism centred on the other aspect of the game.
France play Ireland in Dublin on March 12th, with the French going into the game as clear underdogs.
But Sella believes people should give Laporte time, saying that the French team gets better every game and will be world champions in two years' time.
